<div class="why-container">
  <div class="why-header">
    <h1>Why Local Marine Spatial Planning?</h1>
    <p>Connecting National Vision with Community Action</p>
  </div>

  <!-- The Problem & Solution Section -->
  <div class="why-section">
    <h2>The Challenge</h2>
    <p>Tanzania's coastal regions face mounting pressures. Fish populations are declining as gear intensifies and fishing grounds shrink. Mangrove forests are cleared for aquaculture and development. Young people leave villages because fishing incomes are no longer reliable. Tourism operators compete with fishers for access to the same waters. Government agencies work in silos, often pulling in different directions. Meanwhile, national policy frameworks exist, but translating them into local action remains difficult.</p>
    
    <p>Traditional, top-down marine management hasn't solved these problems. Neither has ignoring the resource management needs altogether. The gap between national policy and local implementation is where problems fester.</p>
    
    <p><strong>This is where Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) comes in.</strong> LMSP bridges the gap between national policy frameworks and community-level implementation, creating a two-way system where national goals are grounded in local reality, and communities see real benefits from planning.</p>
  </div>

  <!-- Core Principles Section -->
  <div class="why-section">
    <h2>What LMSP Delivers</h2>
    
    <div class="benefit-grid">
      <div class="benefit-card">
        <h4>üë• Communities Empowered</h4>
        <p>Coastal communities gain genuine agency in managing their marine resources rather than having decisions imposed from above. When communities lead, they own the outcomes.</p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="benefit-card">
        <h4>üìö Knowledge Integration</h4>
        <p>Local ecological knowledge‚Äîdeveloped over generations of living from the sea‚Äîcombines with scientific expertise. This creates richer, more robust understanding than either alone.</p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="benefit-card">
        <h4>üíº Sustainable Livelihoods</h4>
        <p>LMSP protects and enhances livelihoods for fishing communities. It's not conservation at the expense of poor fishers; it's conservation that works with them and benefits them.</p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="benefit-card">
        <h4>üîó National Support</h4>
        <p>Bottom-up local planning supports national conservation goals and MSP frameworks. Local initiatives are more likely to succeed when aligned with and supported by national policy.</p>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <!-- Governance Structure Section -->
  <div class="why-section">
    <h2>How LMSP Connects Scales</h2>
    <p>LMSP works because it creates a functional connection between national policy and community action. Here's how it works:</p>
    
    <div class="governance-diagram">
      <div class="governance-level">
        <div class="level-icon">üèõÔ∏è</div>
        <div class="level-content">
          <h4>National Level</h4>
          <p>Policy frameworks, national MSP objectives, monitoring standards, and budget allocations provide the overall direction and enabling environment.</p>
        </div>
      </div>
      
      <div class="governance-level">
        <div class="level-icon">üó∫Ô∏è</div>
        <div class="level-content">
          <h4>Regional/District Level</h4>
          <p>Coordination between multiple communities, resource management oversight, capacity building, and ensuring alignment between communities and national frameworks.</p>
        </div>
      </div>
      
      <div class="governance-level">
        <div class="level-icon">üé£</div>
        <div class="level-content">
          <h4>Local/Community Level</h4>
          <p>Direct community engagement, livelihood considerations, site-specific marine spatial planning that reflects local ecology, economy, and social dynamics.</p>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
    
    <p>This three-level structure is critical. Communities don't implement in a vacuum‚Äîthey need national policy support, regional coordination, and access to data and expertise. Conversely, national policies without local understanding often fail to deliver real change on the ground.</p>
  </div>

  <!-- Key Linkages Section -->
  <div class="why-section">
    <h2>Key Linkages Between National & Local</h2>
    
    <div class="linkage-flow">
      <h4>üîó Four Critical Connections:</h4>
      <div class="linkage-step">Policy Integration: LMSP initiatives align with national MSP objectives while respecting local contexts and conditions</div>
      <div class="linkage-step">Data Contribution: Local initiatives feed valuable data and implementation insights to national monitoring systems</div>
      <div class="linkage-step">Stakeholder Coordination: Multi-level governance structure ensures all voices are heard and power is distributed fairly</div>
      <div class="linkage-step">Adaptive Management: National frameworks evolve based on lessons from local implementation experiences</div>
    </div>
    
    <p style="margin-top: 20px; font-size: 14px; color: #666;">Think of it as a dialogue, not a hierarchy. Local communities inform national policy. National policy provides support and coherence to local efforts. The result is ocean governance that is both locally grounded and nationally coherent.</p>
  </div>

  <!-- Two-Way Benefits Section -->
  <div class="why-section">

      <div class="success-indicator">Cumulative impact assessment across the entire coastline‚Äîwe understand how local actions combine nationally</div>
      <div class="success-indicator">Resilience building at multiple governance levels‚Äîthe system is robust because it works at all scales</div>

      <div class="success-indicator">Government coordination improves‚Äîagencies work together toward shared marine objectives instead of at cross-purposes</div>

    <h2>Why LMSP Matters Right Now</h2>
    
    <p><strong>üåç Climate change</strong> is hitting Tanzania's coast hard. Ocean temperatures rise. Storm patterns shift. Fish migrations change. Communities need governance systems that can adapt quickly to these realities. LMSP's adaptive management approach‚Äîwhere plans are reviewed and adjusted based on what communities observe‚Äîis essential for climate resilience.</p>
    
    <p><strong>üíº Blue economy pressures</strong> are mounting. More actors want access to ocean resources: aquaculture companies, energy projects, shipping, oil/gas exploration, tourism. Without spatial planning that clearly defines who does what where, conflict is inevitable. LMSP provides the framework for managing these competing uses fairly.</p>
    
    <p><strong>üêü Fish stocks are under stress</strong>. Many species are overharvested. Traditional top-down fishing regulations haven't stopped decline. LMSP engages fishing communities in managing their own fisheries, creating ownership and sustainability at the source.</p>
    
    <p><strong>üë• Young people are leaving</strong> coastal communities because fishing livelihoods are no longer viable. LMSP creates opportunities‚Äîin alternative livelihoods, in community management roles, in benefit-sharing from tourism or conservation initiatives‚Äîthat make staying on the coast worthwhile.</p>
    
    <p><strong>üèõÔ∏è Tanzania is a leader</strong> in advancing marine governance. Our national MSP framework is well-developed. Our communities are engaged. Our government is committed. LMSP takes advantage of this moment to create something transformative.</p>
    
    <div class="highlight-box">
